subject: Re: [junit] Proposition (?) [WAS Re: Why doesn't JUnit count asserts]
msgSnippet: ... Agreed. ... everybody much happier. Agreed. Well, from http://www.wireless.net.id/map/, west java seems to be covered, but not central java (java.lang?).
messageBody:
>An open-source coverage tool (does one exist?) is the tool to develop.

Agreed.

>As I said: a coverage tool with automatic coverage % analysis will make
everybody much happier.

Agreed.

Well, from http://www.wireless.net.id/map/, west java seems to be covered,
but not central java (java.lang?). :)

Seriously, I couldn't find an open-source one, except :
http://sourceforge.net/projects/codewitness/ which has nothing to offer for
now.
http://starship.python.net/crew/garyp/jProf.html which looks old, and
doesn't really do coverage.

Mathieu


----- Original Message -----
From: Vladimir Bossicard
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, July 24, 2001 7:10 PM
Subject: Re: [junit] Proposition (?) [WAS Re: Why doesn't JUnit count
asserts]


> Of course, even if the counting is not done in the assert class, the
assert
> class still has to be modified to emit the an event or something similar.

and it will be a real mess... I don't think that plug-ins are the way to go
for counting assertions. If you want to throw events each time you
evaluates an assert you have to modify the assert class and have static
listener. If you don't have static listeners, as a TestCase object is
created for each test method, you have to register each listener to the new
TestCase object... what a mess!

I really think that counting assertions is not an issue. It's not because
you have x,000 assertions that your program is well tested. An open-source
coverage tool (does one exist?) is the tool to develop.

I am personally against the count of assertions because:
- the count is not consistant between failed and successful runs
- the count does not tell you anything about the quality of your tests

As I said: a coverage tool with automatic coverage % analysis will make
everybody much happier.

I am ready to change my mind if somebody can prove me that counting
assertions provides more information than analysing the coverage percentage.

-Vladimir
